conclusion: To determine how shadows A, B, C, and D change, consider the direction and angle of the light relative to the objects casting the shadows.
Light source is initially positioned above and slightly to the front, casting shadows directly behind the objects.
Shadows A, B, C, and D are directly behind the respective objects in the image.
When the light source moves to the back left, shadows will shift to the front right relative to the objects.
The angle of the light becomes more oblique, causing shadows to elongate.
Shadow A (Blue Object) moves to the front right of the blue object.
Shadow B (Egg) moves to the front right of the egg.
Shadow C (Black Object) moves to the front right of the black object.
Shadow D (Battery) moves to the front right of the battery.
Shadows become longer and thinner due to the more oblique angle of the light.
When the light source moves to the back right, shadows will shift to the front left relative to the objects.
The angle of the light remains oblique, causing shadows to elongate similarly to the back left movement.
Shadow A (Blue Object) moves to the front left of the blue object.
Shadow B (Egg) moves to the front left of the egg.
Shadow C (Black Object) moves to the front left of the black object.
Shadow D (Battery) moves to the front left of the battery.
Shadows become longer and thinner due to the oblique angle of the light source.
When the light source moves to the back left, shadows shift to the front right and become elongated.
When the light source moves to the back right, shadows shift to the front left and also become elongated.
